title: The people being single lifetime, at the end of their lives, will think that it is a pity that they don't get married; The people who get married, at the end of their lives, will think it is a pity that they don't keep being single, right? - Quora

response.answer_text: Jack, thanks A2A. Sorry, I don’t get the impression that, in terms of relationships, people operate under a universal “the grass is always greener on the other side of the fence” algebraic formula. Culture, sub-culture, religion or lack thereof, gender, family, age… just to name several, all play a role in creating imperatives and attitudes about relationships and status. Some feel marriage is a must, others want nothing to do with it, and still others are ambivalent. Add to that messy pot of stew is the underlying assumption that marriage and the state of being single are the only two valid means of existing in the world. What of the Catholic Priest that chooses celibacy? What of the couple that never weds yet loves each-other for life? How does the formula account people that divorce yet stay good friends and yet do not regret marriage nor longed to be single when they were a couple? (*cough* *cough* the writer clears his throat while waving his arms and pointing to himself) Nah, people and relationships are far too complicated than to go walking along and scratching one’s head thinking, “If only…”

That’s kinda a topic that my sister and I talked about just recently. she asked if I decided to get a divorce would I remarry? I said hell no. I’m at a point in my life I have 1 child who is 9 and I will not let another man be in my daughter’s present, he will not steal my peace, and he damn sure isn’t going to come in my life and leave because things got a lil hard for him. I’m sorry for feeling this way, but I do. I can see myself alone with my child and us doing just fine. I want her father in it, but if he chooses to be with someone else I’ll let that happen and move on. 🤣🤣🤣🤣Period….😂😂😂
